awd_titl_txt: Enhancing helicity-dependent optical interactions in inversion-asymmetric materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical description: The human eye has evolved to perceive the intensity and color of light. However, polarization provides an additional data-rich channel for information - a property is beautifully embodied by mantis shrimp and scarab beetles, species which see circularly polarized light. Many inversion asymmetric materials - including chiral molecules and atomically-thin materials - also preferentially 'see' (that is, absorb) left- or-right circularly polarized light, but only weakly; in fact, the differential absorption of left and right circularly polarized light is nearly five orders of magnitude less than these materials' absorption of unpolarized light. This project enhances the optical absorption and emission of circularly-polarized light in molecular and monolayer materials through the design, synthesis, and characterization of new materials and nanostructures that control light-matter interactions. By increasing chiral light-matter interactions, the research increases the efficacy and reduces the unwanted side effects of pharmaceutical drugs; reduces the toxicity and environmental impact of herbicides and pesticides; and facilitates efficient quantum optoelectronic information processing. As part of the project, the Principal Investigator is engaging in outreach and mentoring with K-12 students and teachers, giving particular attention to underrepresented groups; developing new undergraduate and graduate curriculum; and implementing a national theatre production via a playwright residency.

Technical description: Many inversion-asymmetric materials, including chiral molecules and certain van der Waals materials, exhibit a differential absorption of left and right circularly polarized light that is nearly five orders of magnitude less than their absorption of unpolarized light. Such weak differential absorption prohibits applications including single molecule circular dichroism spectroscopy, all-optical chiral resolution, and efficient valleytronic data encoding for quantum information. This project focuses on enhancing helicity-dependent optical absorption, emission, and carrier relaxation in molecules and monolayered materials. The approach is based on nanostructured materials known as metasurfaces, which, when placed in the near-field of a molecular or monolayer sample, precisely control the amplitude, phase, and polarization of light. Full-field electromagnetic simulations are used to design metasurfaces for strong chiral-optical absorption and emission. In parallel, high-quality factor dielectric metasurfaces are fabricated and a suite of optical and atomic force microscopies are developed to characterize how the metasurfaces enhance molecular and monolayer circular dichroism, photoluminescence, and enantioselective absorption. Finally, the metasurfaces are used to manipulate electron spin orientation and carrier dynamics in molecular and van der Waals materials with broken inversion symmetry. Conclusions drawn from the project are expected to find applicability in all-optical enantioselective sensing and separation as well as quantum optical information generation, transmission and storage.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Optical information is typically encoded in the intensity and wavelength of light. However, its polarization state provides an additional data-rich channel for information. At the macroscale, this property is beautifully embodied by mantis shrimp and scarab beetles, which have evolved to see circularly polarized light. At the nanoscale, many inversion asymmetric materials - including chiral molecules and van der Waals materials, also preferentially 'see' (that is, absorb) left- or-right circularly polarized light. This property has been utilized to determine the secondary structure of proteins, the chiral purity of pharmaceuticals and agrochemicals, and most-recently, to enable new opto-electronic and spintronic devices with two-dimensional (2D) materials. Unfortunately, many inversion-asymmetric materials exhibit a differential absorption of left and right circularly polarized light that is nearly five orders of magnitude less than their absorption of unpolarized light, prohibiting applications including few-to-single molecule circular dichroism spectroscopy, all-optical chiral resolution, and efficient valleytronic data encoding.

 

In this project, we demonstrated routes to enhance helicity-dependent optical absorption, emission, and carrier relaxation in chiral molecules and inversion-asymmetric 2D materials. Our approach is based on nanostructured photonic materials, which, when placed in the near-field of a molecular or monolayer sample, can precisely control the amplitude and polarization of light. We used full-field electromagnetic simulations to design nanostructures and metasurfaces that enable efficient chiral-optical absorption and emission from materials. We fabricated high-quality factor dielectric metasurfaces and used a suite of optical and electron microscopies to characterize how they enhance molecular circular dichroism, photoluminescence, and enantioselective absorption (i.e., Kuhn's dissymmetry factor). We also explored how these metasurfaces can manipulate electron spin orientation and carrier dynamics in 2D materials with broken inversion symmetry and strong spin-orbit coupling, focusing on transition metal dichalcogenide monolayers.

 

Specific outcomes of our work include: 1) Creating Si metasurfaces that enable detection of circular dichroism by a monolayer of optically active molecules, opening the possibility for asymmetric photolysis with lower energy requirements; 2) Creating Si metasurfaces that enable nanoscale localization of all-optical magnetic switching with lowered laser fuence thresholds, as well as enhanced magneto-optical responses for light-assisted reading in spintronic devices; and 3) Creating Si metasurfaces that enhance the circular-polarized emission from excitons in monolayer materials for quantum information sciences.

 

This grant has supported (partially or in total) eight research papers in peer reviewed journals, and several patents. The PI and participating students and postdocs have actively disseminated their research discoveries and results in various conferences, workshops, and department colloquia. We believe that sharing the broader impacts of our work offers a significant return on investment, and organized scientific tutorials and demos for budding STEM scholars and high-school teachers; delivered community lectures; and implemented a playwright residency, leading to development of a full play performed in the Bay Area. The participating students and postdocs have now graduated to top positions in policy (including an OSA Congressional Fellow) and academia (as Assistant Professors at top US and International Universities).

 

Our work provides an important foundation, rooted in photonics, to help address global challenges in information, energy, the environment, and health. For example, our research could enable facile synthesis of chirally-pure compounds, thereby increasing the efficacy and reduce the unwanted side effects of pharmaceutical drugs, as well as reducing the toxicity and environmental impact of herbicides and pesticides. In parallel, our work could enable efficient classical and quantum optoelectronic information processing, based on emerging valleytronic band engineering in atomically-thin materials.
